III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 (1) Visitation and Family time; in person
Section contact.
Description
(1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
• A plan of visitation for each child in foster care
consistent with the child’s service plans, as required
by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to assure the safety
and wellbeing of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation From 6/29/2022 (date of removal) to present. At no time have the
supervising agencies parenting and sibling visit policies been
followed prior to the PPH on 7/19/2023. Not only has the minimum
amount of parent and sibling times been followed, but the
negligence also goes beyond that and has been a serious
detriment to not only the children themselves but the relationships
between the mother and the children. In addition, it has been a
serious detriment to the relationship between the children as
siblings. FCW worker makes false statement in her reports that
are given to the Court/Judge. She states falsely that, "sibling visits
are happening according to law".
Investigation Review of case history in MiSACWIS. The children (8) in this
allegation range from the ages 1,2,3,4,6,8,9, and 13. The children
were removed from their parents’ home on 6/29/2022, due to
alleged improper supervision, physical abuse, physical neglect,
drug exposed infants and substance use. The parents’ home has
been involved with 14 different investigations with DHHS since
2014. Currently, the children are placed with relatives and
unrelated relative foster homes. The children are located in
McMillian, MI., Escanaba, MI., Sault S. Marie, MI. and Newberry,
MI. The permanency goal is adoption per court order of
7/20/2023.
Complainant was interviewed on 9/19/23 via telephone. She
reported basically the same information in the allegation and/or
complaint. She added that she has moved from Traverse City,
Michigan back to Newberry, MI. on July 26, 2023, to get all of her
2

grandchildren to move with her and to have Youth A, who is in
residential placement with her, be closer to his siblings. The
Complainant sent this Consultant an email where she disclosed
information and policies regarding DHHS not following DHHS
contract policies. It was explained to the Complainant prior in a 2-
hour conversation with her that DCWL does not regulate DHHS
policies and that DCWL regulate the violations of Child Placing
Rules.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed on 9/1/2023 via TEAM
conference. She reported that beginning with June 29, 2022, the
Judge ordered DHHS to provide one visit per week per child with
their parents. However, the court understands that with the
number of children in this family, the distance of each placement
and the amount of travel for DHHS workers, he is ordering less
frequent visits then DHHS policy states at the time. It was noted
that the children during that time was place in McMillian, MI.,
Escanaba, MI., Sault S. Marie, MI., and Traverse City, MI. Foster
Care Worker provided the barriers for the sibling and parental
visits. She reported the barriers as winter weather in the Upper
Peninsula, lack of transportation, lack of high -speed internet, and
the distance between placements. The Foster Care Worker broke
down the distance as following:
• Youth A was placed with his father from August 2022-
October 2022 in Ishpeming Michigan for a total of 232
miles round trip to Newberry, Michigan.
• In October 2022, Youth A’s father signed a POA to
maternal grandmother who resided in Traverse City
Michigan. This is a 390-mile round trip to Newberry,
Michigan.
• Youth B is placed with her father in Escanaba Michigan.
This is a 226-mile round trip to Newberry Michigan.
• Youth C is placed with her father in Sault Ste Marie
Michigan. This is a total of 130-mile round trip to
Newberry, Michigan.
The Foster Care Worker reported that DHHS provided gas cards
to support parenting and sibling visits to both mother and relatives.
She said these were provided on many occasions.
The Foster Care Worker presented the social work log contacts
that included sibling visits and parenting visits between the
parents and the siblings. She reported during this time frame only
one visit was missed on 7/23/22. She said the sibling visit was
attempted to be scheduled at the Besse Park in Escanaba
3

because the caregivers were going to Escanaba to go shopping.
She said one of the caregivers asked if the siblings could get
together on this day as they would be in Delta County. She said
she texted the caregivers of four of the children for a sibling visit
but, none of the caregivers were available to meet at the park with
the caregiver who requested the visit for this day.
The Foster Care Worker reported that at a court hearing dated
7/19/23 the biological mother can have supervised visits with
Youth A only. She said the court order was filed for termination of
the parents right and the permanency plan now is adoption.
Document Review:
• Placement History
Youth A – (4 placements) Relative – 6/27/23
Youth B – (2 placement) Licensed unrelated foster home -
8/7/22.

8/5/22.

7/28/22.

6/29/22.
Youth F – (1 placement) Licensed unrelated foster home –
6/29/22.
Youth G – (4 placements) Relative – 7/17/23.
Youth H – (2 placements) Relative – 7/17/23.
DHHS Visitation plan for the Children and parental visits:
• The visitation plan created on 6/29/22, for visitation type
were supervised visits, phone calls, and sibling visits. The
duration of the visits were 2 hours, video calls are allowed
but must be supervised. Visits take place at a local park,
local DHHS office depending on the weather.
• It is noted the court allowed parenting time visits for Youth
A effective 7/20/23 only. There was a reason for exception.
The judge ordered DHHS to provide one visit per week per
child with their parents. The court understands that with
the number of children (8) in this family, the distance of
each placement and the amount of travel for DHHS
workers, he ordered less frequent visits then DHHS policy
states at this time.
MiSACWIS Visitation Social Work Contact Log of sibling

Updated Service Plan dated 4/25/23 -7/23/23, recorded the
following parental visits with children:
• 5/8/23, 5/15/23, 5/21/23, 6/12/23, 7/5/23, 7/6/23, 7/18/23.
DHHS Policy FOM 722.06I – Sibling Visitation Exceptions:
• The policy states, “Caseworkers must engage caregiver,
and children when age – developmentally appropriate in
development in the in-person and virtual sibling contact
plan. Monthly in-person sibling contact is required
unless…. the distance between the sibling’s placements is
more than 50 miles and one child is placed with a relative.”
Analysis Based on the documentation reviewed and the foster care worker
interview, it is not determined that the agency is in violation with
the rule. As noted, the siblings had numerous sibling visits
beginning with their removal on 6/29/22. Based on the Updated
service plan dated 4/25/23 – 7/23/23, the children had parental
visits with their biological mother. Currently, the biological mother
can only have visits with Youth A and they are supervised visits.
Youth A as of 7/26/23, has moved back to Newberry to be closer
to his siblings and mother. Although the Division of Child Welfare
Licensing does not regulate DHHS policy, in this instance this
agency is in compliance with DHHS Policy FOM 722.061 and the
rule.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
5

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted following allegations that the Chippewa/Luce/Mackinac County DHHS failed to follow required visitation policies for eight siblings in foster care and their mother from June 2022 onward. The investigation, which reviewed case history, interviewed the complainant and the foster care worker, and examined documentation, found numerous documented sibling and parental visits and noted that the court had ordered less frequent visits than policy due to the large number of children and significant geographical distances between placements. The report concludes no violations of licensing rules were established. Although the agency faced logistical challenges, the investigation found it complied with the relevant rule and internal policy regarding visitation.
